title: Authorizes the creation of utility facility coordinating committees in N.Y. city
summary: Authorizes mayor or chief executive officer of any city having a population of one million or more persons to establish a utility facility coordinating committee to develop and implement procedures under which each utility corporation and corporation authorized to install and lease underground conduit facilities providing service in the city shall cooperate with such city in developing plans for the removal, protection or replacement of any facilities of such corporation which are to be disturbed or affected by the laying out, establishment, construction, maintenance, operation, alteration or discontinuance of any street, sewer and drainage system, or water supply system in such city, and cooperate with such city where removal, protection or replacement of such facilities is undertaken; details minimum cooperative procedures to be undertaken in such cases.

BILL NUMBER:S1903

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the public service law, in relation to cooperation in the
removal, protection and replacement of utility facilities in cities
having a population of one million or more persons

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
This bill would authorize cities having a population of one million or
more persons to create a "utility facility coordination committee,"
including both city and utility corporation representatives, to:
develop and foster strategies and procedures for effective and cost
efficient cooperation in dealing with interference problems inherent
in essential municipal construction projects in streets crowded with
public gas, electric, steam, telephone and/or waterworks facilities.
These approaches would include: efficient notification and data
exchange;
effective coordination and planning; development of cooperative
bidding processes; and a feasibility study on comprehensive long-term
strategies coupled with analysis of costs to both ratepayers and
taxpayers.

A report to the legislature, with recommendations, is due January 1,
1991. Within six months of the creation of a utility facility
coordinating committee, at least one project would be selected to
ascertain the practicality and effectiveness of joint-planning
agreements under which removal, protection and replacement work for
utility corporations would be carried out under the city's contract.
Actual performance would be carefully monitored and audited. The bill
includes projects financed or carried out by New York City Water Board.

JUSTIFICATION:
The City of New York's proposed State utility facility-relocation
legislation, promotes increased cooperation between local government,
in cities with a population of one million or more, and utilities
located in such cities will result in a more equitable and effective
process for minimizing community impact of projects involving street
openings. This legislation authorizes the creation of a new mechanism
- a "utility facility coordinating committee" - to enable more
detailed planning to occur when a street, water, sewer or drainage
project will disturb utility facilities, or a utility project will
affect City facilities. Joint planning prior to the bidding of city
projects will promote more comprehensive agreement between involved
parties as to the extent, nature and cost of the work involved, thus
reducing costs to utility ratepayers and city taxpayers. Also,
expected is a reduction in the time necessary to complete a project,
to greater convenience the public.

Better coordination planning between cities and utilities is an impor-
tant and necessary first step, which is anticipated to lead to further

steps to simplify and streamline joint city-utility project planning.
These next steps could include joint-planning agreements and
cooperative bidding of work. This proposed legislation requires that
within six months of the establishment of a utility Facility
Coordination Committee in a city with a population of one million or
more, a "sample" project be selected in order to further explore this
process. In New York City, six projects have already been selected
tentatively for planning with the intention of utilizing
joint-planning agreements and cooperative bidding.

As these six projects progress the City and utilities will be better
able to assess the effectiveness of joint-planning agreements and
cooperative bidding. Previous pilot pre-engineering projects in New
York City for water main construction have reduced utility relocation
costs by almost two thirds. Additionally, we will be able to audit
whether reasonable and fair formulas can be developed to allow for
projects to be paid for on a periodic, rather than a per project,
basis. This bill lays a solid basis for the development and
institutionalization of effective new procedures that will result in
greater equity for all concerned. New York City's utility
facility-relocation proposal establishes an area in which it and
private utilities can meet to better resolve the complex problems
'associated with joint projects. This proposal institutes a process
to enable both sides to balance interests and reach fair agreements
on matters such as the scope of work and associated costs. The
cost-saving and time-saving features of this plan are to the ultimate
benefit of all citizens residing in localities addressed by this
legislation.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect immediately, provided however that
procedures implemented pursuant to section 119-d of the public
service law, as added by section one of this act, shall not apply to
projects undertaken prior to July 1, 1992 or after June 30, 2012,
except as is otherwise provided in subdivision 6 of such section.
